name: Newtonian Mechanics Equations
description: Exploring fundamental equations that describe motion, forces, and energy in classical mechanics.

cards.title: Kinematic Equations & Motion Analysis
cards.description: Understanding the equations governing motion in one and two dimensions.
bulletpoints: Define the kinematic equations for constant acceleration: \[ v = v_0 + at \], \[ x = x_0 + v_0 t + \frac{1}{2} a t^2 \], \[ v^2 = v_0^2 + 2a x \].
Analyze projectile motion using horizontal and vertical components: \[ x = v_0 \cos(\theta) t \], \[ y = v_0 \sin(\theta) t - \frac{1}{2} g t^2 \].
Interpret motion graphs for displacement, velocity, and acceleration.

cards.title: Newton's Laws of Motion
cards.description: Exploring the fundamental principles of force and motion.
bulletpoints: State Newton's three laws: \( \sum \mathbf{F} = m \mathbf{a} \), the principle of inertia, and action-reaction pairs.
Apply force equations: \[ \mathbf{F} = m \mathbf{a} \] to analyze dynamics in different scenarios.
Examine friction, tension, normal force, and net force problems in real-world applications.

cards.title: Work, Energy, & The Work-Energy Theorem
cards.description: Understanding the relationship between work, kinetic energy, and potential energy.
bulletpoints: Use the work-energy theorem: \[ W = \Delta KE = \frac{1}{2} m v^2 - \frac{1}{2} m v_0^2 \]
Define gravitational potential energy: \[ U = mgh \] and elastic potential energy: \[ U = \frac{1}{2} k x^2 \]
Apply conservation of energy: \[ KE_i + PE_i = KE_f + PE_f \]

cards.title: Momentum, Impulse, & Conservation Laws
cards.description: Studying momentum principles and their applications in collisions.
bulletpoints: Define momentum: \[ \mathbf{p} = m \mathbf{v} \]
Apply the impulse-momentum theorem: \[ \Delta \mathbf{p} = \mathbf{F} \Delta t \]
Use the conservation of momentum for collisions: \[ m_1 v_1 + m_2 v_2 = m_1 v_1' + m_2 v_2' \]

cards.title: Rotational Kinematics & Torque
cards.description: Understanding angular motion and rotational forces.
bulletpoints: Define angular displacement, velocity, and acceleration: \[ \theta = \theta_0 + \omega_0 t + \frac{1}{2} \alpha t^2 \]
Relate linear and angular motion: \[ v = r \omega \], \[ a = r \alpha \]
Define torque: \[ \tau = r F \sin(\theta) \] and rotational equilibrium.

cards.title: Angular Momentum & Rotational Energy
cards.description: Studying the conservation of angular momentum and rotational kinetic energy.
bulletpoints: Define angular momentum: \[ L = I \omega \] and its conservation: \[ \sum \tau = \frac{dL}{dt} \]
Calculate rotational kinetic energy: \[ KE_{rot} = \frac{1}{2} I \omega^2 \]
Apply conservation of angular momentum in systems with no external torque.

cards.title: Simple Harmonic Motion & Oscillations
cards.description: Understanding periodic motion in mass-spring and pendulum systems.
bulletpoints: Define the equation of motion for a mass-spring system: \[ x(t) = A \cos(\omega t + \phi) \]
Use Hooke's law: \[ F = -kx \] and angular frequency: \[ \omega = \sqrt{\frac{k}{m}} \]
Analyze the motion of a simple pendulum: \[ \omega = \sqrt{\frac{g}{L}} \]

cards.title: Newton's Law of Universal Gravitation
cards.description: Studying the effects of gravity in celestial and planetary motion.
bulletpoints: Define the gravitational force equation: \[ F = G \frac{m_1 m_2}{r^2} \]
Apply Kepler's laws of planetary motion to orbital mechanics.
Analyze gravitational potential energy in planetary systems: \[ U = -G \frac{m_1 m_2}{r} \]

cards.title: Damped & Driven Harmonic Motion
cards.description: Exploring oscillatory motion under external forces and damping effects.
bulletpoints: Define damped motion equation: \[ m \ddot{x} + b \dot{x} + kx = 0 \]
Study resonance effects in driven harmonic oscillators: \[ x(t) = A_0 e^{-\beta t} \cos(\omega t) \]
Apply these principles to mechanical, electrical, and biological systems.

cards.title: Center of Mass & Equilibrium
cards.description: Understanding the motion of extended objects and static equilibrium.
bulletpoints: Define the center of mass: \[ \mathbf{R} = \frac{\sum m_i \mathbf{r}_i}{\sum m_i} \]
Analyze equilibrium conditions: \[ \sum F = 0, \quad \sum \tau = 0 \]
Apply these concepts to balancing problems and stability analysis.
